title: ‘We are open for business’
story: CROSSGAR is open for business.Thatrsquos the message from traders a week on from claims that the village and neighbouring Ballynahinch were at the heart of a coronavirus outbreak which infected a number of people.The business community say last weekrsquos reports have had a ldquodevastating impact on the village which is Covid- free, with the safety of all staff and customers the number one priority.A number of businesses mdash which had only reopened a number of days after a raft of lockdown restrictions had eased mdash are angry that Crossgar was wrongly implicated as having the virus.It subsequently transpired that there were  coronavirus cases,  of which are believed to relate to one family in the Ballynahinch area who are not connected to any business.Contact tracing was implemented and all those affected have been contacted by public health officials.A care home on the outskirts of Crossgar closed to visitors as a precaution last week, while three homes in Ballynahinch went into lockdown as the Covid- reports circulated.Business owners in Crossgar insist that the safety of staff and customers is their absolute priority and that there is strict adherence to social distancing and sanitisation requirements.Businesswoman Jenner Graham of AJrsquos Diner said last weekrsquos media reports have had a major impact on trade across the village, leaving many in the business community angry and upset.She explained she had no issue with care homes closing as a precaution, insisting that what they did was perfectly understandable given what happened to similar facilities during the global pandemic.Mrs Graham said the media spotlight was wrongly shone on Crossgar with rumours about alleged cases of coronavirus ldquocompletely blown out of proportion.She said people had been ldquospooked about coming to the village at a time when businesses were adhering to all guidelines to ensure that their respective premises are safe.Mrs Graham went on: ldquoWe are all trying to keep our staff employed under dficult circumstances but the message which last weekrsquos media reports sent out did not help.ldquoI have spoken to several traders and while there is a lot of concern at what happened, the overriding message is that the Crossgar is very much open for business.ldquoNone of AJs customers or members of staff have ever tested positive for Covid- and our absolute priority has always been their safety.She added: ldquoWe also continue to take all necessary and thorough precautions in line with regulations regarding social distancing and sanitisation and hope that everyone will continue to support local business at this uncertain time.Rowallane councillor, Terry Andrews, said businesses in Crossgar are very much at the heart of the districtrsquos economy and encouraged people to eat out and shop locally.ldquoWe depend on local businesses so much and we should be supporting them at this time. Many businesses had to close for over three months as a result of coronavirus lockdown measures and are on the slow road to recovery. It is essential that they have the publicrsquos backing and support at this critical time, he said.ldquoIt is more important than ever that we support our local shops, cafes, bars and restaurants who collectively provide signicant employment, supporting many families.Cllr Andrews said local businesses and ious retail outlets ldquohave all gone the extra mile, working to implement guidelines and regulations designed to keep staff and customers safe at all times.He added: ldquoCrossgar is one particular part of the district where businesses have worked hard to ensure that people are safe, whether shopping or out for something to eat.ldquoThe village is home to a number of businesses, many of them family-owned, and it is important that we support them at this time, alongside other businesses across the district. The business community needs our support more than ever..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass artist makes model of shipwrecked WW2 vessel
story: ARDGLASS artist William Mulhall recently completed work on a stunning model replica of a ship which ran aground on the Lecale coast more than  years ago.The Georgetown Victory ran aground at Killard Point, near Ballyhornan in , while on its way from Australia to Glasgow.All of the , servicemen aboard, who were due to be demobbed following the end of the Second World War, were rescued.Local farmers responded to the emergency and helped transport the troops to RAF coaches to take them to nearby Bishopscourt where they were served breakfast.A military convoy subsequently ferried the troops to an army barracks in Belfast where several hundred boarded a passenger steamer en route to Glasgow, their original destination.William has described the time he spent on making the new model as a ldquolabour of love and is keen to garner as much information as he can about the ship.While aware of what happened to the Georgetown Victory, he would like to broaden his knowledge of the disaster which occurred just a short distance from his home.William says he is keen for anyone who can help to either contact him by telephone or pop into his shop in his home village where they will also be able to see his model.ldquoI am pleased to have completed the model and it was special to work on a project that I remember my father talking to me about, he said.ldquoThe Georgetown Victory is an important part of the history of Lecale and I know there are many people out there who have more knowledge about then disaster than me. I would like them to get in touch.William said he has heard many reports about the disaster, including one relating to men from Portaferry who allegedly took a piano off the ship.The Georgetown Victory was a lsquoVictory Shiprsquo and was built in  at the Fortfield Shipyard at Bethlehem, Maryland, in the United States. She weighed in at , tons and was powered by two steam turbine enginesSays William: ldquoThe vessel was registered at Baltimore and when it left Fremantle for Glasgow with , Royal Navy men and marines due for demob. The crew mistook Strangford Lough for the River Clyde and the ship ran aground  yards off Killard Point, with her back breaking just forward of the bridge within a few hours of stranding.The Georgetown Victory had been converted from a cargo ship to a troopship able to transport up to , troops, with her cargo holds converted to bunk beds and hammocks stacked three high for hot bunking. In the cargo hold, mess halls and exercise areas were also added.Entering service near the end of the war, the Georgetown Victory and  other Victory troopships were given the task of transporting the troops home as part of Operation Magic Carpet. The vessel was operated by the American Export Lines.The ship departed Sydney with , troops steaming to Glasgow, stopping for water and fuel at Fremantle in Australia, Colombo in Sri Lanka and Aden in Yemen via the Suez Canal.On April , , just before midnight, the ship ran aground hard, at near top speed,  yards south of Killard Point.All of the servicemen aboard were rescued by leboats and breeches buoy to a tug started at about am.William said local people can remember some men wading ashore through heavy fuel oil from the stricken vessel to be cared for in nearby homes. The Cloughey and Newcastle leboats were also launched to help.Winter storms subsequently broke the wreck into two parts with all remaining portable gear not already taken by looters removed and the ship abandoned. The ship sections were salvaged in  and consigned to a breakerrsquos yard at Troon in Scotland.With his resplendent model now complete, William could be forgiven for sitting back on his laurels. But he has no intention of doing so.His next project will be making a model of the SS Bereby, a British merchant steamer built in  and owned by the Elder-Dempster Line.In , the vessel, which was carrying military stores and general cargo, was wrecked at Ringvad Point, near Gunnrsquos Island, while en route from Liverpool for Takoradi.Anyone who can assist William with information about the Georgetown Victory is asked to contact him on    or pop into his shop in Quay Street..prettyPhoto

title: Call to be vigilant of seals
story: VISITORS to Minerstown beach are being urged to tread carefully to protect seals and the arearsquos rich ecology.The appeal has been issued by Newry, Mourne and Down Council with officials particularly keen for boats and jet skis to stay away from key areas.Minerstown beach mdash popular with locals and visitors alike ndash is located within the Strangford and Lecale Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and, along with neighbouring Tyrella, is part of the Murlough Special Area of Conservation and area of special scientic interest.Noted for its honeycomb worm reefs and harbour seals, Minerstown was particularly busy over recent months with many people furloughed from work as part of sweeping coronavirus lockdown measures visiting the beach where harbour seals which are protected by law.Then animals use the rocky outcrops just offshore as so-called haul-out and pupping sites with the peak pupping season running from the end of June to mid-July.Pups wean from their mothers approximately four weeks after birth and, for this reason, council officials are asking all watercraft owners to stay away from the haul-out areas until the end of October.Council staff say that with seals very sensitive to disturbance, it is important for people to leave them alone.They say the area between the beachrsquos high and low tide marks is an important site for sand flats with boulders containing the honeycomb worm reef, a Northern Ireland priority marine feature.The worm lives in tubes constructed from small pieces of sand and shell fragment cemented together forming reefs between pebbles and boulders in the middle shore.Council officials have explained that these delicate reefs are under threat from beachgoers walking in the area and from vehicles driving on the beach.ldquoUnderstanding the impact that our actions can have and following simple advice will protect the health of the wildle at Minerstown beach and protect it for future generations, said officials.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said people were spoilt for choice when it came to local beaches and the waterways, with Minerstown one area which has seen an increase in use during the lockdown period.ldquoUnfortunately, an increase in the use of the beach and its surrounding waters can cause some problems for the local wildle, he said.ldquoThe council is asking beach goers to help it protect these beauty spots and the associated plants and animals by being mindful of how their actions can impact on the environment.Describing Minerstown as a ldquovery special place, she said it was important for local wildle.Cllr Devlin added: ldquoWhile we want our residents and visitors to enjoy the wonderful coast that our district has to offer, we also want to protect the habitats and species that make this place so special.ldquoPlease help us to protect this area by not taking vehicles onto the beach, stay away from the seal haul-out sites, always keep dogs under control and not allow them to chase birds. Also please take your litter home..prettyPhoto

title: Clarke converts penalty to help Down secure win
story: DOWN again flattered to deceive when getting the better of a plucky Longford in the second round of the All-Ireland Qualiers in Newry on Saturday night.Down will now travel to Offaly in the next round andthey win that game they will take on one of the four beaten provincial finalists for a place in the All-Ireland quarter-finals.The incessant, heavy rain made le dficult for both sides, but Down looked world beaters in the opening half before again fading the longer the game went on.It took a disputed th penalty from Martin Clarke to give Down a bit of breathing space as Longford hit back strongly in the second half and gave the home side numerous problems.Longfordrsquos Francis McGee, who scored - of his sidersquos tally, opened the scoring after just minutes as Down got used to playing Dan Gordon in an unaccustomed role at full back.Gordon, who replaced the injured Benny McArdle, was a revelation in a two-man full back line with Darren OrsquoHagan and manager James McCartan was more than happy with the Loughinisland manrsquos performance.ldquoPeople in the stand probably thought that our new defensive line-up was a bit radical, but Dan played full back against Louth and Laois in friendly games and we know just what he is capable of.Kalum King and Ambrose Rogers helped Down settle and unanswered points from Mark Poland, Benny Coulter and John Clarke pushed them into a three-point lead.A second McGee free reduced the deficit to two points, but Down simply moved up a gear and started to play the kind of football they are capable of.Martin Clarke converted a free before he split the posts from play and Danny Hughes tagged on another point as Down really looked the part.Longford responded with through another McGee free, but Down finished the half on a high and points from Poland and Martin Clarke gave them a - to - lead at the break.Noel Farrell grabbed the first score of the second half when he pointed a free, but this was cancelled out by a similar score from Hughes. Paul Barden kept Longford in the hunt when he scored a magnicent point from the sideline.Down continued to play well in patches and corner back Declan Rooney joined in one attack before lofting the ball over the par after some delightful passing.McGee cancelled this point out before Clarke converted from the penalty spot to give Down an eight point lead with  minutes remaining.Longford were helped a little when Downrsquos Kalum King was red carded after picking up two yellows and they took full advantage with McGee finding the back of the net with a clinical finish.Martin Clarke and McGee swapped frees before Hughes broke away in injury time to finally kill off a courageous Longford outfit.Down: B McVeigh, D Rooney , D Gordon, D Rafferty, D OrsquoHagan, J Colgan, C Garvey, A Rogers, K King, D Hughes , M Poland , B Coulter , C Maginn, J Clarke , M Clarke . Subs: K. McKernan for Garvey, C Laverty for J Clarke, P Fitzpatrick for Poland, A Carr for Maginn.Longford: D Sheridan, D Brady, B Gilleran, D Reilly, S Mulligan, E Williams, S Hannon, D Masterson, B McElvanney, P Dowd, P Barden , K Mulligan, F McGee , B Kavanagh, S McCormack. Subs: N. Farrellfor Hannon, P Kelly for Mulligan..prettyPhoto

title: Construction work continues at new 30%2C000sq ft building
story: WORK is progressing at pace on a new poundm distillery outside Ballynahinch.The new , sq ft Hinch distillery is situated on the Killaney estate, near Temple, and produced the craft Hinch Irish Whiskey and Ninth Wave Gin brands.When the two-storey building opens for business, there will also be an interactive visitor centre, coffee shop, retail area, outside courtyard space and multi-purpose events spaces.As work progresses, it has been confirmed Marcon has been awarded the contract to fit-out the eagerly awaited new distillery which will create an estimated  jobs over a five-year period.The Belfast firm will work in partnership with world-renowned design company Drinksology to deliver Dr Terry Crossrsquo vision to create this unique and first of its kind facility in Northern Ireland.Fully trained guides will bring visitors on an interactive and informative journey that will include a history of Irish whiskey and its unique distilling process, tutored tasting sessions, a specic gin tour and the opportunity to produce and bottle their own gins.And the purpose-built visitor centre will be able to accommodate more than , visitors a year.Dr Cross, Hinch Distillery chairman, said it was being launched to provide visitors with a highly dferentiated product and experience that coupled the production of quality spirits with a story and heritage.ldquoWe hope it will become an attraction in its own right and offer guests a real understanding of the skills and methods needed to produce our spirits, he said.The distillery produces a premium whiskey collection of ying maturities and profiles, all originally sourced from some of the most reputable whiskey producers in Ireland.The companyrsquos premium gin brand, Ninth Wave, which takes its name from Celtic mythology, is ldquoother worldly and, alongside the Hinch Time Collection, has been making noise across the globe, while Hinch Distillery has secured listings in  countries globally.Marcon will be responsible for delivering the full fit-out of the new distillery which will include all specialist joinery items, such as feature bars, bespoke wall ling, fixed furniture and floor and ceiling finishes.Marcon Fit-Out director Mark OrsquoConnor, said the company was ldquoreally proud to have been awarded what he described as a ldquoprestigious project.He continued: ldquoGiven the ambition of the facility to be a leading visitor attraction, the fit-out will be of the highest standard.ldquoAll of the specialist joinery items will be produced in our manufacturing facility, giving us the opportunity to showcase Marconrsquos quality finish. It will be really exciting to see the completed distillery when it opens this year.Sustainability lies at the heart of the new distillery and the same applies for the fit-out phase of the build.Since the projectrsquos inception, the team at Hinch Distillery has worked closely with the Woodland Trust to plant , trees throughout the estate, with Marcon making a major contribution to the projectrsquos environmental, social and economic sustainability targets.The company has ensured that all timber products are procured from sustainable sources and are FSC accredited and it is also dedicated to producing zero waste to landfill during the project.In addition, Marcon has confirmed that it is committed to using local companies within its project team, providing employment opportunities within the local economy.The company has also ensured that trade apprentices get the opportunity to contribute to the delivery of the project, both in its specialist joinery workshop and within its supply chain..prettyPhoto

title: Cricket is back at last
story: ITrsquoS a case of better late than never mdash after months of waiting, cricket is back this Saturday.Local clubs Downpatrick, Saintfield, Dundrum and Drumaness Superkings are all raring to go after the Covid- pandemic lockdown and also looking forward to renewing old rivalries.Downpatrick and Saintfield are both in Section  of the NCU League, while Dundrum and Drumaness are in the same group of a combined Sections  and .As a result of the shortened season all NCU competitions will be played under  over rules.The eight Premier league clubs will compete for the Robinson Services Cup, playing each other once with the top four going through to the semi-finals.The eight clubs will also play a knockout competition for the Lagan Valley Steels T Cup with the winner lining up in the All-Ireland T finals.The  Senior League  clubs will play each other once for the Robinson Services Trophy as well as a knockout competition for the Lagan Valley Steels T Trophy.Senior Leagues  and  are completely reorganised with the  clubs ided into three groups of four to compete for the Robinson Services Bowl. The teams will play each other home and away with the group winners and the best runner-up proceeding to the semi-finals.Given the changes the NCU has decided that there will be no promotion or relegation in .At Downpatrick club captain Ross Boultwood will be hoping the first eleven can carry on from where they left off last season.In one of the most dramatic finishes to a season in living memory, Downpatrick produced a late run of victories to narrowly avoid relegation on the last day.Downpatrickrsquos opening fixture on Saturday is away to Donaghcloney Mill and the locals will be hoping to get off to a good start.Also eagerly awaited is the trip to Saintfield on Saturday, August .Paul Tate is back as captain the second eleven. Only six games will be scheduled for the seconds but friendlies can also be arrangednecessary.Saintfield, who were promoted to Section  last year, are away to Ards on Saturday. Survival is the priority this season, but they have plenty of firepower in their ranks.Team captain Gareth Harrison will form a useful fast bowling partnership with TJ McCavera and they can also call on left arm spin twins Ethan Hanna and Patrick Telford, while  year-old Adam Reid a highly talented wicketkeeper and destructive batsman.At Dundrum, who are at home to Dunmurry on Saturday, new captain James Martin is confident that his players will be ready to compete with any team in the section.For the first time in a decade there is a very good first eleven squad of , including new signings Davy Glover from Victoria, Mark Topping from Dublin and Bruce Topping, who has come from Donaghcloney.There are also three new players from England. All-rounder Liam Kearsley and Charlie Rudge both played for Madeley in Shropshire and Jack Lambert, another good all-rounder, has been impressive in the nets.Adam Symington and Patrick Calvert have also looked impressive in practice, so deciding the batting order will be dficult.The selection committee will definitely have many tough decisions to make, but competition for places can only be good news for the villagers.The club also believes the  over format will suit their aggressive batsmen, so expect plenty of fireworks at the Meadow.There should also be fireworks at Drumaness Superkings, formed at the end of last year following the merger of Drumaness and Belfast Superkings.The club has taken over the maintenance of the ground from Newry, Mourne and Down Council and will be fielding three teams this season.The firsts open up with a trip to Belfast International Sports Club and have plenty of talent in their ranks.Team captain Mohammed Ismail will open the batting with James Cunningham, while the bowling duties will be shared by Muhammed Abid, Gary Walsh, Neil Walsh and Gary Moore.Club chairman Darren Oldroyd says he canrsquot wait for the action to begin.ldquoBecause of the merger we have secured the future of cricket in Drumaness, he said. ldquoWe have a nice ground, good support and plenty of history..prettyPhoto

title: Fibrus expanding broadband service throughout district
story: BROADBAND provider Fibrus is working in Killyleagh and Ballynahinch as it expands its service throughout South Down.Kilkeel, Rostrevor and Warrenpoint will also be included in the infrastructure improvement plans described by the company as representing a ldquosignicant investment.Fibrus has already completed works in Dundrum, Castlewellan and Newcastle in recent weeks,The companyrsquos chief operating officer, Conor Harrison, said that it adapted its construction operations during lockdown.ldquoThe lockdown period had limited impact on our progress, but we used the time to research and implement the best possible social distancing and safety measures to ensure our employees, partners and residents were protected, he said.ldquoWe adjusted our operations and are now following updated working practices, allowing us to continue with our expansive roll-out.ldquoWe have exciting and ambitious plans for towns across South Down and look forward to providing residents and businesses with a top quality service which they havenrsquot been able to access before. This will revolutionise connectivity, including download speeds and bandwidth, for these communities.Mr Harrison explained that while some aspects of the work may cause some disruption locally, particularly during for construction and digging roads, he said that it would be short-term and they aimed to ldquocomplete this initial phase as quickly as possible.He added: ldquoEnsuring minimal disruption and providing a first class service is central to our work.Communication with local residents in the areas we operate is absolutely crucial for us at Fibrus and we welcome all feedback from those affected by our work..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 15%2C 2000
story: BALLYNAHINCH ndash Senior Roads Service officials have this week been asked to play a key role to improve safety standards for people attending the weekly market in Ballynahinch.Councillor Anne McAleenan has expressed her concern for the safety of people who are regular visitors to a number of stalls which skirt the outskirts of the Department of Regional Developmentrsquos Windmill Street car park in the town.The weekly market now operates at the car park and the town square and Mrs McAleenan said many elderly people who make their way to this area for their weekly shop have to watch out for cars and Post Office vans making their way to a local depot.The local councillor said Road Service officials are responsible for road safety matters and must take whatever action is necessary at the Windmill Street area to protect local residents, in particular the elderly.ldquoRoads Service officials must put more effort into this area. Many old people attend the weekly market and they have a right to be able to do their shopping in safety, she said.Mrs McAleenan said part of the Town Square, the traditional home of the weekly market, was given up to allow work to begin on the townrsquos new one-way traffic system.ldquoAs a result, it now operates at two sites and the Department must realise it has a duty of care to protect shoppers at the Windmill Street area, she added.Mrs McAleenan also urged Roads Service officials to join forces with Down Council officers and members of the Ballynahinch Regeneration Committee to come up with a suitable venue for the traditional weekly market.KILLYLEAGH ndash Demolition work to pave the way for one of the biggest housing developments ever proposed for Killyleagh is currently underway.Developers Hagan Homes have begun demolishing buildings at the former Killyleagh Yarns factory on the Downpatrick Road where it plans to develop  new homes at the sprawling five acre site.It is over a year since the housing firm bought the site for pound.m at a public auction and a mix of new homes is to be constructed over the coming months.They include semi-detached houses, cottages and apartments and the developers are confident the new homes will help regenerate that area of the town.They are promising to provide homes and apartments which boast high quality design, particularly as part of the development site falls within Killyleaghrsquos designated conservation area.But not all the former mill buildings will be bulldozed to make way for the new homes. A number will be retained and developed into apartments to ensure the character of the conservation area is retained.Several old buildings, including the old engine house, will be converted into flats and surrounded by semi-detached homes and cottages.NEWCASTLE ndash Crime is on the increase in the Newcastle area, according to recently published police figures.Latest statistics reveal a particularly sharp increase in incidences of burglary, criminal damage theft and, more specically, theft from vehicles.A total of  criminal damage offences were recorded in   compared to  the year before, while the number of recorded thefts has increased by .Also growing in number are reported cases of frauds, forgery and drug offences committed in the seaside town and outlying areas.Over the past three years, there has been a marked sea-change in the quantities and types of drugs seized by police in the Newcastle area.Whereas cocaine and cannabis accounted for the majority of narcotics hauls in the   period, the past year has seen a greater prevalence of amphetamines seizures.DUNDRUM ndash The sun shone down brightly for the official opening of Down Districtrsquos latest tourist amenity.An pound, holiday development, aimed at addressing the dirty of tourist accommodation in Dundrum, has been completed after seven years of preparation.The tourist centre, funded by the International Fund for Ireland, Down Council and the Department for Social Development, and initiated by the villagersquos regeneration committee, has been hailed by tourist chiefs throughout the district as an ldquoundisputed boost to the local economy.It is hoped the development, which includes a restaurant, tourist centre sand eight self-catering holiday homes, will encourage tourists to spend their holidays at the village.The Tonn Ruray restaurant, a circular building with stunning views over the bay, is now open for parties, seminars and small weddings, while reservations for the holiday homes have already taken off.BALLEE ndash Members of Ballee Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church took to the roads recently to visit a number of other Non-Subscribing churches.But Saturdayrsquos journey was one with a dference, and took place with members in the back of a tractor.The -mile event was organised to raise funds for the restoration of the church hall.Clough, Killinchy and Templepatrick were just some of the towns and villages passed through during the -hour hike, during which nine members took turns at the wheel of the tractor.Church members extend their thanks to Allan Chambers for supplying the tractor and to others who helped throughout the day.STRANGFORD ndash Roads Service officials have this week been praised for carrying out work on a scheme in the Strangford area.Local councillor Peter Craig said he and local residents were delighted work to repair a bank between The Links and Fairways has been completed.Mr Craig said a number of flagstones have been laid in the area and hopes other safety improvements are in the pipeline.DOWNPATRICK ndash A former teacher at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School made a welcometo the Downpatrick school recently.Brother Anthony Furness, FSC, who taught science at St Patrickrsquos in the s, was back in County Down after a long absence.He now lives and teaches in South Africa, but ed to Downpatrick to meet some old friends, in particular Mr Brian Magorrian, the schoolrsquos vice-principal, who retired last week.Mr Magorrian, who was one of his first A-Level students at St Patrickrsquos in the Fties and was taught by Bro Anthony, who also taught at St Patrickrsquos Boysrsquo Primary School before moving to the lsquoRed Highrsquo.A graduate in chemistry, he taught science and went on to introduce A-Level physics at the high school.During his visit Bro Anthony saw some of the schoolrsquos new facilities and enjoyed reminiscing about his years at the school. His other former pupils included Dr Jim Hamill, Michael OrsquoCleary-Clarke, Jim Curran, the former head of science at East Down Institute of Further Education, and Tony Rice, who went on to study engineering.CROSSGAR ndash A local Womenrsquos Institute branch is casting off the traditional image of jam making and flower arranging by launching its very own site on the Internet.Announcing the news of the Crossgar Womenrsquos Institute site the grouprsquos secretary, Sheila McMurray, explained how the idea of a website came about and how the  members of the Institute aimed to dispel the stereotypical image of the organisation.ldquoIt started with the idea that we should do something to mark the Millennium. After much debate the committee decided that since this is very much the information technology age we should develop our own website, she said..prettyPhoto

title: German delight as Annahilt teenager Harper secures win
story: ANNAHILT teenage racing driver Daniel Harper secured a memorable first victory in the Nuumlrburgring Endurance Series in Germany at the weekend.The revised calendar for the  season saw the second and third rounds of the series take place on the same weekend, meaning  year-old Harper and his BMW Junior Team stablemates, Neil Verhagen and Max Hesse, contested a four hour race on each day.If that wasnrsquot already a busy enough schedule, Harper also found himself in the unique position of competing in two cars in the same races ndash identical BMW Mi racing machines for the FK Performance and Walkenhorst Motorsport teams.This was because he and his team-mates needed to complete a set number of laps of the Nordschlee circuit to upgrade their circuit permits. If successful, they would then be able to step up to a BMW M GT for the next round of the series.Prior to each dayrsquos race, there was a -minute qualying session to tackle.On Saturday, Harper starred as he qualied the FK Performance car second quickest in the competitive Mi Racing class, while Verhagen put the Walkenhorst car fth.The  year old started the race behind the wheel of the FK Performance car and moved up to second place on lap two. Edging clear of the pack behind, Harper maximised the rest of his stint to get some crucial experience of traffic management in multi-class racing.After handing the car over to Hesse, Harper had a short break before taking the final stint in the Walkenhorst machine.He ran in the podium places until the closing stages, when a late pitstop meant he eventually led his team-mate home to fth and sixth in class.On Sunday, Harperrsquos attention was focused solely on the FK Performance prepared BMW and a strong start in qualying saw him place them third on the class grid. He went on to start the race behind the wheel, tackling a double stint of over two hours.Staying out of trouble during the busy opening laps, the BRDC SuperStars member fought to second place and held it throughout the early stages. Consistent lap times kept him in touch with the leader and he moved to the front of the class during the first pitstop cycle.A brilliant performance from there saw him post a new circuit lap record for the Mi as he built a lead of  seconds before handing the car over to Verhagen.The American took full advantage of the prime position and led to the finish to secure them the class win.Harper said afterwards: ldquoIrsquom absolutely over the moon to score a victory in class in just our third race together as the BMW Junior Team.ldquoI think everyone is in some shock as we didnrsquot expect to challenge the Mi class experts, let alone beat them in our second true race.ldquoIrsquom pleased with my pace across the event, particularly in race two. I loved my first experience of a double stint and to set a new lap record for the car so late into my run was mega. Neil and Max both drove superbly too and as a team it was a great weekend..prettyPhoto

title: Hall pens new deal
story: BALLYNAHINCH defender Greg Hall has signed a new one year contract at Portadown.Hall arrived at Shamrock Park from Ards in January  and slotted into the right back berth, where he has remained ever since.A firm favourite with the Porrtadown fans, he picked up a injury against Ballyclare Comrades in November which has resulted in him missing the remainder of the season.However, he should be fit and raring to go for the new season as the Portsto the Danske Bank Premiership.In   he picked up the Players Player of the Year award and the Richhill Reds Player of the Year award.Ports boss Matthew Tipton said he was thrilled with Hall signing a new deal, describing him as a ldquomodel professional who has always given his all for the club.He added: ldquoEven though he was injured for a chunk of last season I could see how hard he was working to get back fit for the run-in and Irsquom delighted to have him on board for next season.Hall has also had spells with Loughgall, Lisburn Distillery and Ballynahinch United..prettyPhoto

title: James wins international short story competition
story: A SECOND local young writer has been honoured for his environmentally-themed writing.James Lavery from Ballykinlar has won the international childrenrsquos magazine AQUILArsquos -word short story competition.The  year-oldrsquos story has been featured in a magazine with , subscribers and made the front cover of the magazinersquos recent edition.Jamesrsquo success of the follows fast on of that of  year-old Dara McAnulty from Castlewellan whose debut book, The Diary of A Young Naturalist, has been critically acclaimed.Jamesrsquo story mdash Battle for the Amazon mdash was inspired by Colin Dannrsquos The Animals of Farthing Wood, which tells of a group of woodland animals whose home is set to be paved over by developers.The eldest son of Mark and Alison Lavery, James decided to site his story of survival in the Amazon forest as its ecosystem and animals are under threat due to over mining and logging and the effects of mankind.He said of his story which takes a wry insight into the animal world and its hierarchy: ldquoThe narrator is an eagle called H, I call him the Happy eagle in my story. I came up with the idea for his story by myself, my parents only knew about it when I told them I had won.James and his brothers Connand eight year-old Dara have been home-schooled for two years in a lsquoscreen freersquo learning environment.His mum Alison, who is a teacher, follows a child-centred curriculum, with methods and materials inspired by Maria Montessori.AQUILA is regarded as ldquothe ultimate intelligent read for inquisitive kids and is posted to more than  countries worldwide including UK, Ireland, America, Australia and New Zealand..prettyPhoto

title: Lyons roars to victory
story: CROSSGAR Golf Club hosted its first open competition of the year at the weekend.A large crowd turned out in good conditions for the event, which was sponsored by the Central Bar.Early riser Neil Hanvey set the clubhouse target with  points.Lee Hanna, also an early starter, just fell short with  points but this was enough to secure him third place, beating veteran Davy Hanna on the countback.The winner was Coalisland man John Lyons who continued his early season form, blitzing the field with a magnicent  points.The gross prize, predictably, went to lsquoMr Consistentrsquo Davy Watson and his son, Curtis, claimed the juvenile prize with  points.Damian Bell won the battle of the guests with  points.The ladiesrsquo competition proved a much closer affair with only one point separating the first three.Anne McCart was a little unlucky to miss out on a prize but got some consolation with the only lady to have a two.Elizabeth Patterson got her season off to a good start with the runners-up spot but the winner was a delighted Isobel Hyde who was celebrating her first big win since recently rejoining.The club is grateful to Brian and Kerri-Ann OrsquoHare for their continued support, especially in these trying and uncertain times..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting with minister to support newspapers
story: FORMER Downpatrick man and South Belfast MLA Matthew OrsquoToole has met with Stormont finance minister Conor Murphy to raise the issue of support for local newspapers.The meeting took place a number of weeks after Mr OrsquoToole mdash who grew up reading the Down Recorder ndash called on the Northern Ireland Executive to take urgent action to preserve the vital role of local and regional media in the wake of the Covid- crisis.Mr OrsquoToole said the crisis has highlighted the importance of local and regional media in providing accurate, professionally sourced information.He said whatever the scepticism about some aspects of the national or international media, there are high levels of trust for local and regional media, insisting that people understand these papers exist to serve and give a voice to their communities.The MLA said the coronavirus crisis has led to a collapse in advertising revenue for news media in both print and online, while social distancing restrictions have also hampered print sales.He said the crisis has come on top of nearly two decades of structural challenge for traditional newspapers, with print sales falling and digital giants increasingly monopolising advertising revenue online.Mr OrsquoToole had previously proposed a five-point plan to protect local and regional media and allow it to thrive in the future including a one-year rates holiday for local newspapers and a poundm annual Northern Ireland journalism fund.Welcoming his meeting with the finance minister, Mr OrsquoToole, said he continued to make the case that the Executive must act urgently to save local, regional and community media from a complete collapse.ldquoWe are facing a crisis in our local media which threatens not just the people who own papers, but the resilience of the local communities they serve, said the MLA.ldquoLocal and regional papers are not just sources of information, though that itself is vital, they are the meeting point of people and places. They bind communities together, mitigate against isolation and provide something close to an essential service. It is unthinkable that they would be allowed to collapse.Mr OrsquoToole, who is a former Downing Street press officer, says he also favours a tax on the internet giants.ldquoA number of months ago, I wrote to the Executive to ask them to initiate work on my action plan, which includes a rates holiday for local newspapers, prioritising local media in advertising spend, committing to a poundm journalism fund and to press the British Government to institute a digital information levy on social media giants such as Facebook and Google, he said.The MLA added: ldquoI welcomed the opportunity to engage with the finance minister where I pressed upon him the importance of committing to act to save this vital industry. I hope that he will agree with me and make necessary funds available..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle ADHD Hub reopens to visitors
story: THE ADHD Hub in Newcastle reopened last Friday.Situated in Savoy Lane, the Hub closed in March at the start of the lockdown.It is an autistic contact centre and coffee shop, managed by Janet Cunningham who is assisted by a host of volunteers.The lockdown affected many ADHD and autistic adults and young people who use the Hub and its facilities on a regular basis.The Hub is open Thursday through to Sunday evening. Facilities include an art club, a therapy room and a sensory room.Newcastle Lions Club helped with the reopening to ensure the health and safety of volunteers and visitors was maintained.To help promote the Hub the Lions also agreed to design and supply an advertising standard for the front of the premises.A spokesperson for the Lions said: ldquoThis community-driven, volunteer-led service has helped provide respite for those with ADHD and autism and their families..prettyPhoto

title: Ruairi signs deal with The Ports
story: CASTLEWELLAN striker Ruairi Croskery has signed for newly promoted Dankse Bank Premiership side Portadown.The  year-old has signed a two year contract at Shamrock Park ahead of the - season.Croskery spent four years at Manchester United and featured in the same Un- squad as current first team stars Marcus Rashford and Scott McTominay.After his spell at Old Trafford he ed back to Northern Ireland to sign for Linfield. However, he made just one senior appearance for the Blues, scoring a second half header in a - win over Glenavon at Mourneview Park.From Windsor Park he moved to Warrenpoint Town where he would play under his new manager at Portadown, Matthew Tipton.He helped the club win the Championship in the   season before moving to America.Croskery has spent the last three years at Limestone University in South Carolina where he played for Limestone College in the NCAA D Soccer Championship.While at Limestone he was selected for the Conference Carolinas All-Tournament team in  and in was named as the Conference Carolinas Tournament Most Outstanding player.Ports manager Tipton said: ldquoIrsquom delighted to get Ruairi signed. Hersquos someone I worked with at Warrenpoint before he went to America on a football scholarship three years ago.ldquoWersquove stayed in touch over that time and Irsquom surprised he didnrsquot block my number with me constantly asking when he was coming home to sign for us.ldquoRuairi has the ability to play in any of the forward positions and offers us something completely dferent to what we have now in terms of style of play.He added: ldquoI donrsquot want to put too much pressure on him, but I think hersquos a player our fans will get excited about and one our players will enjoy playing with.On signing for Portadown, Croskery said: ldquoI always kept in contact with Matthew Tipton over the three years I was in America and I told him I would come home to him.ldquoOnce he got the Portadown job I followed him on social media and I feel like Irsquove been here for two years already. Irsquove been speaking to him following the whole thing.Speaking about how he will fit into the system at Portadown, he said: ldquoIrsquoll play anywhere, I started as a striker at a young age played there for five years.ldquoI then played as a number  at Warrenpoint and when I went to America played on the left and right wing. Anywhere in the attack Irsquom fine with that, so Irsquom looking forward to it.Outllining his ambitions for the new season, he added: ldquoIrsquom confident we can do well. Wersquove got a young squad here.ldquoEverybodyrsquos hungry and Irsquom hungry coming in and I think wersquoll do well. Irsquove no doubt that wersquoll stay up and push on from there..prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde couple transform basement into movie room
story: A FAMILY of movie buffs from Seaforde are enjoying their own silver screen experience during lockdown after designing a cinema in their basement.For many, the loss of enjoying the latest blockbuster at the cinema has been a big social adjustment.Interior designer Jacqueline Hamilton , and her quantity surveyor husband Tonywere diehards for their regular cinema haunt, often accompanied by their son, Rudi , daughter Daisyand niece Dulcie Maguire , who all regularly went to the Downpatrick Omniplex before lockdown.Such was their love for the movies that a plan was devised to make their own cinema at their home last year.And the finishing touches have finally be put on the basement move theatre during lockdown.Jacqueline, who had previously worked in post-production in the film industry and now runs Seaforde Interiors, designed the cinema.She said her inspiration came from Londonrsquos Soho and the set of BBCrsquos Strictly Come Dancing.ldquoI used to work in post-production in Soho where we did commercials, features and TV shows. We had the most beautul Art Deco Vaudeville theatre for celebrities, actors and directors to view their work. So I always loved it and knew I wanted to create something like that when it came todesigning the cinema, explained Jacqueline.Jacqueline reeled in her professional interior design skills, repurposing household items and getting inspiration from the dance showrsquos judgesrsquo table for her home cinema.She said: ldquoTony and I moved back home from London and built our home where we had a basement constructed. But it became a storage area and the kids were sitting more or less in the middle of it.ldquoWe drove up to Belfast and got wadding to line the walls. When we ran out of wadding, we just used old duvets. We covered the wadding with red velvet. That made the room soundproof.ldquoWe are cocooned watching a movie and a massive thunder storm would pass without us even hearing it. Tony did the building work by and the kids helped. We called them the film crew.ldquoI also got gold paint and mixed that with glitter to give the old-style feel of the movie room. We made a bar thatrsquos inspired by the judgesrsquo  table on Strictly Come Dancing. I was watching the show one night and thought Irsquod like to make something like that.The Art Deco-style columns were Billy bookcases from Ikea that we painted. I had a mirror bought for me that needed a place to hang it and we put that in the bar where it really suits. A relative bought us a popcorn machine for added authenticity.She said that from creating the mood board for the project to when it was completed took four weeks, but it really was not used until lockdown.ldquoBefore the Covid- restrictions, the cinema was something we had started and used a bit. When lockdown came and the cinemas closed, the kids were never out of our cinema, she said.ldquoThe kids can go in there and watch their Netflix and Disney Plus mdash we have Sky, Netflix and every other movie and plus channel going now during lockdown so we can get the newly released movies as they are streamed.ldquoNow therersquos so much satisfaction with it. Itrsquos something special we designed and built as a family and now use as a family. Itrsquos a special place because we all have invested our time, love and effort into it.However, there are no plans to rule out trips to the cinema after they are allowed to reopen.Jacqueline added: ldquoWe will continue to support our local cinema. Our home cinema is great but therersquos nothing like the real thingThe movie theatre, whether it be modern or old-style, is a magical place and I hope we all continue going to the movies and supporting our cinemas for many years to come..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to former council chairman
story: GLOWING tributes have been paid to former SDLP councillor Patsy Toman who sadly passed away last week. He was .Mr Toman, who is survived by his we, Anne, daughter Bronagh, sons Patrick and Niall, and the wider family circle, represented the Ballynahinch area on the former Down Council.He fought six successful local government election campaigns and was a distinguished former chairman of the council after his appointment in .Tributes to Mr Toman mdash who was interred last Friday following a service at St Macartanrsquos Church in Loughinisland mdash have been led by Baroness Margaret Ritchie, the former South Down MP, South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillors Dermot Curran, Terry Andrews and Billy Walker.Committed to his family and the wider community, Mr Toman was held in high regard by many, including his former council colleagues. He was a principled man who helped everyone, regardless of their politics and always stood up for what he believed to be right.A passionate defender of the Ballynahinch electoral area, he lobbied hard to secure investment and was a key player in the drive to secure a new bypass around the market town.Mr Toman made a signicant contribution to the district and a number of organisations, including Loughinisland GAC. He was the clubrsquos former cultural officer and treasurer.Leading the tributes to her friend and former council colleague, Lady Ritchie said the community of Loughinisland and further afield had lost a man of ldquoimmeasurable integrity and the epitome of hard work and resilience. She also said that she had lost a ldquotrue friend.Lady Ritchie revealed that she had known Mr Toman since she was six years old, explaining that in his early le, he worked as a shop assistant in McKeatingrsquos general provisions store in Downpatrickrsquos Scotch Street.ldquoMy mother ordered her groceries in the shop every week and they were delivered on a Saturday. I can recall Patsy working in that shop and sometimes he delivered our groceries, she recalled.ldquoIn our many conversations, he recalled those visits and how I was only ever interested in the lemonade bottles that were in the grocery box. At that early stage of his le, Patsy was in a hurry and, above all, he was super efficient to get the job done. His attention to detail was legendary.Lady Ritchie said that she next met Mr Toman at a meeting of the SDLPrsquos Down District Executive in Dundrum in June .ldquoPatsy obviously knew who I was because he asked meI was still in Belfast. I indicated that I had ed home and he told me that he looked forward to working with me in the party.ldquoOnce again I noted a man who wanted to get the work done on behalf of the people. Patsyrsquos career in the grocery business continued when he had his own vegetable van, travelling theand breadth of parts of East Down.Describing Mr Toman as an ldquoindustrious inidual, Lady Ritchie said he was a ldquochampion of the underdog and a man of integrity, who fought relentlessly for the rights of farmers, social housing tenants and rural residents on a wide range of issues including planning applications.She continued: ldquoPatsy was a man of the community. He was a member of Ballynahinch Credit Union, Magherlegan Pipe Band, the Monday Club in Drumaness and Loughinisland GAC, as well as numerous organisations associated with the former Down Council. Patsy was a true Gael and was involved in the cultural and Scor activities of his home club.ldquoWhen I worked with the late Eddie McGrady MP, Patsy used to call into the Downpatrick constituency office every Monday and would have met up with the late Cllr Peter Craig.ldquoThere was fierce rivalry between the Saul and Loughinisland GAA teams and those matches were fought out again in the Scotch Street office and latterly in Saul Street, with Patsy and Peter also glorying in the fortunes of the Down GAA team in the early s.Lady Ritchie said Mr Toman always put the needs of people first, with this clearly reflected in the background work he did on behalf of the Loughinisland families following the  massacre at The Heights Bar in the village.ldquoPatsy was shaken with emotion and grief about the killing of six innocent men and the images of that night on June  lasted with him until he was overtaken by his illness and his untimely death. He always stood solidly with the families in their fight for justice and truth, she continued.Lady Ritchie said Mr Toman was involved in the politics of the SDLP for a long time and was a founder member and chairman of the partyrsquos Drumaness branch.He was elected to Down Council in  and subsequently re-elected in , , ,  and  and while he retired from elected politics in , he remained active in the community.ldquoPatsy was a stalwart on the East Border Region Committee and the Ards Down Rural Partnership, continued Lady Ritchie.ldquoI fought many elections with him and he kept driving everyone to go the extra mile to achieve better representation. AndPatsy had an issue that required a resolution, he pursued you until he got an answer, applying that same approach for all of his constituents.Lady Ritchie said Mr Toman had been a ldquotrue, loyal friend for many years and was delighted and honoured to attend his th birthday celebrations in April of last year.ldquoPatsy always confronted you with his political problems which were not major at all. Such was the loyalty and bond between Patsy and myself that whenever I was ill with breast cancer, both he and his we Anne arranged a special Mass for me the day before my surgery. I will never forget that and I am eternally grateful to Patsy and Anne for their personal support to me during my political and personal le, she added.She added: ldquoPatsy was an extremely loyal inidual a family man who cherished his we, children and grandchildren. He was a man of deep Christian faith, a person of immense integrity and an extremely hard worker and defender of the rights of the underdog..prettyPhoto

title: Unease over A%26E reopening plans
story: BARONESS Margaret Ritchie has urged health chiefs to ldquoend the uncertainty over theof the Downe Hospitalrsquos emergency department.Her call comes after the South Eastern Trust confirmed that it plans to reopen the Downpatrick hospitalrsquos minor injuries unit from August as part of staged restoration of all emergency services.A number of services mdash including accident and emergency and minor injuries mdash were removed by the health trust at the end of March as part of its response to the coronavirus pandemic.Baroness Ritchie says these services need to be restored as soon as possible, given the continuing reduction in Covid- cases.When the health trust closed the Downpatrick hospitalrsquos emergency department, its critical care staff and some equipment were relocated to the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald as the organisation prepared for what it described as ldquothe biggest challenge it has ever faced.Health chiefs said they needed to reshape hospitals and other services on a temporary basis to maximise its ability to ldquomanage the surge in demand for services due to Covid-.While the endoscopy service and other day case surgical work has recommenced at the Downe, Baroness Ritchie said the local community was eager for theof the emergency department and that senior health chiefs must provide clarity on this issue.ldquoOn Monday of last week, the South Eastern Trust confirmed that it would provide a date at the end of July when the Downersquos emergency department would reopen, with the re-opening of the minor injuries unit at the beginning of August ,marking ldquohe stepped progress to the opening the ED, she said.ldquoHowever, last Friday, the publication of the joint Department of Health South Eastern Trust plan for rebuilding services within their respective areas between July and September stated that Trust officials will lsquoexplorersquo the feasibility of reopening the ED service.Lady Ritchie warned that this represents a ldquomarked dference of emphasis and that the Trust needs to claryit is deviating from its commitment to provide a date at the end of July for the reopening of the Downersquos ED.She continued: ldquoThe South Eastern Trust needs to provide a date for the re-opening of emergency services in Downpatrick and I have urged it to do so as soon as possible. I hope it is not obeying the tune of centralising services in Belfast. The local population deserves better.The former South Down MP said that as Northern Ireland was being reopened for business following a reduction in the number of Covid cases, ldquonormal services at the Downe hospital should resume.Lady Ritchie said anything which falls short of what was previously in the hospital would ldquorepresent a lack of faith and trust.She added: ldquoIt is important to remember that the real ing of the Downe Hospital with its suite of services and consultant physicians is directly linked to the AE provision.ldquoI have told both the health trustrsquos chief executive and health minister Robin Swann that anything that falls short of that requirement will be unacceptable and present our community with an intolerable position.Last week, health officials insisted that emergency services removed from the Downe as part of sweeping changes to help tackle the coronavirus pandemic will be reinstated. In addition, officials branded claims that the service will notand be replaced with a daily minor injuries service as ldquoinaccurate and misleading.The health trust says that it hopes to be in a position to confirm a date for theof AE services to the Downpatrick hospital by the end of July and that it remains totally committed to the Downe and its staff..prettyPhoto

quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. story: Arson attack in the dead of night targets home in loyalist-dominated city neighbourhood – PSNI say lives were at riskDUP’S Carla Lockhart condemns online abuse of Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill, two years after Upper Bann MP suffered similar attacksNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPoliticsCoronavirus measures: Decision on mandatory face masks in shops not expected until late next weekIt is expected to be almost a week before the Stormont government will decide whether or not to make facemasks compulsory in shops to help suppress Covid-.By Adam KulaFriday, th July , : am""A man riding abus in Belfast, after face masks were made compulsory on public transportIn the meantime, the government is merely advising their use, rather than demanding it.The news comes a day after health minister Robin Swann came out in favour of the practice becoming mandatory, adding that both the chief medical officer and the chief scientic adviser at Stormont agree that masks should be worn “in retail stores and other indoor spaces”.However the Executive Office said the next time when all Northern Ireland’s ministers will meet is expected to be Thursday, July  – and it is understood that is when a decision will be taken. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Face masks are already mandatory in Scottish shops, and England will follow on July . In Wales they are not compulsory in shops instead, the government there says its medical advice is to support “the public’s right to choose” .If people do decide to wear face coverings, it says these “should be made up of three layers, as set out by the World Health Organisation”.In the Republic of Ireland, on Wednesday the new taoiseach announced that face coverings must now be worn in all shops, retail settings and shopping centres.There are already legal regulations requiring the mandatory wearing of masks on public transport in the Republic , and the taoiseach Micheal Martin said that now “regulations with details on enforcement and penalties will be formulated” in relation to masks in shops.Speaking yesterday, when she met Mr Martin while he visited Belfast, Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill said: “The chief medical officerhas made it very clear that while perhaps at one stage of this pandemic he was not convinced of the merits of face coverings, we are now in a space where he thinks that is the case.“We will look at all of that evidence and then make a decision on that. But I think that as more and more people are moving around as we come to the end of the shielding period, there is probably a logical reason as to why face coverings should be a thing that we are all .”Briefing the media separately from Arlene Foster,she added that Northern Ireland’s policies needed to be aligned with the Republic’s, and that the jurisdictions’ chief medical officers were working closely together.According to the Department of Health, the total number of Covid- deaths recorded as of yesterday in Northern Ireland was .The frequency has slowed markedly from a peak on April to now, when it has become increasingly routine to have no deaths reported each day, ever since the first death-free day on June .A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: sam mcbride arlene foster seems be tearing historic dup policy perhaps without even realising
story: The distortion of history has at its worst fomented sectarian hatred of ProtestantsNoah Donohoe death: PSNI say reports that they had already leafleted area with appeals for information may be due to ‘misunderstanding’NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPoliticsSam McBride: Arlene Foster seems to be tearing up historic DUP policy, perhaps without even realisingJust seventeen days ago, Arlene Foster and Michelle O’Neill set out for the first time details of a bill which they are ramming through the Assembly at such speed that it will probably be law within a fortnight.By Sam McBrideSaturday, th July , : am""Arlene Foster has jointly brought the proposal forward – despite it undermining key aspects of long-standing DUP policyThey presented the proposed legislation – the blandly-titled Executive CommitteeBill – as a somewhat boring and technical tidying-up exercise and until recent days it had attracted no controversy.But there is now reason to believe that what the first and deputy first ministers want MLAs to nod through at breakneck speed could be the most signicant change to how the Executive operates since the St Andrews Agreement  years ago.However, what really lies behind the move by the DUP and Sinn Féin leaderships for now remains puzzling. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...What is going on at the top of the DUP is particularly intriguing because one of the architects of St Andrews – Mrs Foster’s former senior special adviser Richard Bullick – has now said that this bill represents “the most signicant rolling back of the St Andrews Agreement and will signicantly undermine the ability of the Executive to prevent ministers acting without collective agreement”.After months in which the Executive has been almost wholly focussed on dealing with the pandemic, there has been little legislation brought to the legislature.But on July , Mrs Foster and Ms O’Neill appeared before the Assembly committee which scrutinises their department to reveal aspects of the bill and to ask that it be fast-tracked by accelerated passage, thus limiting scrutiny.However, the previous day had seen Ms O’Neill and myriad Sinn Féin colleagues openly breach her own public health advice, meaning that discussion of the legislation essentially became an appetiser to the main course of Ms O’Neill having to publicly account for her actions.With Mrs Foster describing it as “a very short bill” which was “literally a one-clause bill when you look at the substantive nature of the piece of legislation”, neither the First Minister’s words nor her body language suggested this was highly signicant.She said it was necessary because of the Court of Appeal ruling in  – the Buick case – in which judges ruled against civil servants giving planning permission for a huge incinerator in the absence of a minister.One of the court’s reasons for ruling as it did was that it said the issue involved more than one minister’s responsibilities – a so-called ‘cross-cutting issue’ which has to be referred to the Executive as a whole.Mrs Foster told MLAs that the bill would clary that issue because otherwise the Executive could find itself having to take planning decisions, despite not being best placed to do so.But for some reason the bill goes far further and redefines the meaning of cross-cutting for all ministerial decisions.The First Minister indicated that she understood the bill’s sweeping nature, saying that “we wanted to deal with it right across government, and not just in terms of the Department for Infrastructure”.The First Minister’s argument was somewhat curious because the DUP leader was taking issue with the fact that the court had placed an expansive interpretation on the term ‘cross-cutting’. That means that there are a large number of areas in which a minister’s power to act alone is curtailed because another minister can argue that they would be impacted by their decision.What she did not say was that the court’s interpretation was essentially the DUP’s long-standing interpretation of the term – the party had for years argued for a wide definition, something which gave it more scope to have a role in other ministers’ decisions.In fact Mrs Foster had personally gone to court – on a question of planning policy – when she was Enterprise Minister in  to challenge a decision by fellow minister Mark H Durkan. Mrs Foster’s grounds of challenge were centred on precisely this area – the argument that he had exceeded his powers because it was a cross-cutting issue.For her part, Ms O’Neill said it was “really, really important that we get this bill enacted before the end of July to allow the planning minister to be able to take a number of planning decisions”.But Ms O’Neill, whose opening statement to the committee lasted less than a minute, gave even less sense that she comprehended the signicance of what she was jointly proposing.After less than  minutes of evidence and consideration, the committee acquiesced easily in the ministers’ request for accelerated passage of the bill.The committee’s SDLP chairman, Colin McGrath, said: “I think it’s fairly straightforward it’s not an overly complex bill.”In fact, theof the bill is deceptive it deals with an exceptionally complicated juncture between messy Stormont politics, statute and case law, balancing the ability of ministers to take decisions for which they are accountable against the Executive’s desire to maintain some sort of coherence rather than an administration of ministers constantly acting to thwart each other.Five days later, the issue came to the whole Assembly. Only four MLAs opposed reducing scrutiny of the bill. But just one MLA – People Before Profit’s Gerry Carroll – voted against the bill itself at second reading.Sinn Fein’s Pat Sheehan supported it as “a sensible and effective approach”, Alliance’s Andrew Muir said that the bill was “necessary” and even DUP MLAs who had enthusiastically endorsed St Andrews now queued up to say that a bill which a key DUP architect of that agreement says unravels that deal is crucial.DUP veteran Mervyn Storey said that “obviously, this is a necessary requirement”. Party colleague William Humphrey said it was “vital that we have legislation that allows Northern Ireland to go forward”. Fellow DUP MLA Christopher Stalford said “anything that makes government quicker and more reactive to the needs that confront it is only to be welcomed”.Even the Executive’s arch-critic, Jim Allister, accepted that the bill was “necessary”.But last week Mr Bullick, Mrs Foster’s former adviser and a lawyer by training, began tweeting his unhappiness at what was unfolding.He said that one provision in the bill “puts [ministers] in a much stronger position in the event of a legal challenge” and was “based on a misreading of the case law”.Central to the DUP’s thinking at St Andrews was an attempt to stop Sinn Fein ministers from going on solo runs, such as Martin McGuinness’s unilateral abolishment of the Eleven Plus in .Critics of St Andrews argued that it led to sluggish government where decisions languished untaken for months or years and Stormont’s two dominant parties carved up power in backroom deals.But the DUP was willing to accept that because it saw Sinn Féin as a party with far more radical goals than its own essentially the DUP accepted that the price of thwarting a swashbuckling republican agenda was to have lethargic centralised decision-making because it could stall or halt what it didn’t like.This bill does not wholly undo the St Andrews changes, but the very fact that Mr Bullick – the strategic brain of the DUP for years who has not spoken out publicly against the party since leaving his role three years ago – is forthrightly warning the DUP in public about this issue shows that it has caused alarm among some of those most intimately involved in constructing St Andrews.It is no surprise that Sinn Féin is endorsing something which weakens provisions designed by the DUP to curb its power.But is the DUP consciously making a major policy sht, or is a momentous decision being taken in ignorance It is possible that Mrs Foster has calculated that the inertia of the post-St Andrews decade of devolution was a mistake and that it is now better to give ministers more freedom to take speedy decisions – eventhat means Sinn Féin decisions which unionists will dislike.But Mrs Foster has nowhere made that argument or even indicated that she grasps the import of what she is doing.It is equally possible that Mrs Foster, the minister who didn’t even bother to read the legislation which she asked MLAs to vote for in  to set up the RHI scheme, is not across the detail of what is a complex area.If that is the case here, that flaw could prove enormously damaging to her own interests, even– as with RHI – this legislation sails through with scant opposition when MLAs debate it on Tuesday.——— —————— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: there no point churches meeting sinn fein says former presbyterian moderator

" fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Dr Hamilton, who for more than  years has been a minister at Ballysillan in a part of Belfast, the north, which was a flashpoint during the Troubles.He has long been involved in reconciliation work.While not referring to the funeral of the IRA leader Bobby Storey, to which thousands of people turned up, Rev Hamilton says: “A working principle has now been established [at Stormont] that people can do what is right in their own eyes, irrespective of the impact on wider society.”The blunt intervention is highly unusual from a senior churchman.His comments have been welcomed by the former IRA bomber Shane Paul O’Doherty, a born-again Christian who has turned against republican terrorism, and who has been particularly critical of the Roman Catholic church for appearing to have dropped its past opposition to flags in funerals and to have softened its past criticism of republicans. He told the News Letter last night: “The churches have been to the fore in incorporating the brazenly unrepentant IRA mafia into the body politic.“I welcome Rev Hamilton’s comments but it is a bit late for the churches to be complaining that Sinn Fein is misbehaving.”• Dr Hamilton’s letter click here——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services.
